revision.text:
[[File:1929 Timberworkers Strike.jpg|thumb|Outside [[Darlinghurst, New South Wales|Darlinghurst]] Court House where several timber workers were being tried by [[Lionel Lukin (judge)|Judge Lukin]] for non-compliance with the Award; 7000 workers attended]]
The '''1929 Timber Workers strike''' was a labour dispute in Australia caused by [[Lionel Lukin (judge)|Judge Lukin]] of the [[Compulsory arbitration|Arbitration]] Court handing down an [[Award (Australian industrial relations)|industrial award]] decision on 23 December 1928 to reduce the wages and increase the hours for 20,000 timber workers from a 44-hour week to a 48-hour week. It was the first strike in Australia after the onset of the [[Great Depression]].
An initial response by workers at mass meetings on 3 January in Melbourne, Sydney and Adelaide was to refuse to work the four hours extra stipulated by the Lukin award. This then precipitated the employers applying to the court that a strike existed. The penalties of the Arbitration Amendment Act, enacted in 1928, were then invoked. The urban nature of timber mills meant that industrial action was concentrated around the working class areas of the affected cities, notably Glebe in Sydney.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Diane|first=van den Broek|title=Partners in Protest: The Case of the 1929 Timber Workers' Strike|journal=Labour & Industry: a journal of the social and economic relations of work|year=1996|volume=7|issue=2|page=145|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10301763.1996.10669165#preview|doi=10.1080/10301763.1996.10669165}}</ref> The dispute widened with carters and crane drivers striking in solidarity. A special conference of the [[Australian Council of Trade Unions]] (ACTU) on 7 February 1929 agreed to extend the strike to a general movement; to boycott the Federal Industrial Court; and for the conduct of the strike to be managed by the ACTU Disputes Committee.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dixson|first=Miriam|authorlink=Miriam Dixson|title=The Timber Strike of 1929|journal=Historical Studies: Australia and New Zealand|year=1963|volume=10|issue=40|pages=479–492|doi=10.1080/10314616308595252|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/10314616308595252|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref>
On 25 February, Justice Lukin ordered a secret ballot of the timber workers in Victoria and New South Wales. This was the first attempt to enforce a secret ballot in an industrial dispute. On 1 March Lukin imposed a fine of 1000 on the Timber Workers Union, followed by a fine of 50 on [[Jack Holloway]], Secretary of [[Victorian Trades Hall Council|Melbourne Trades Hall Council]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Wyner|first=Issi|title=Chapter 11: Strike!|url=http://www.takver.com/history/myunion/myunion11.htm#1929|accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> A protest meeting outside the [[Sydney Trades Hall]] on 25 March was attended by 25,000 trade unionists. At this meeting 3000 strikers publicly burnt their ballot papers. The crowd then marched to Hyde Park where an effigy of Justice Lukin was burnt. On an interesting aside, Judge Lukin was the first judge of the Supreme Court of the ACT.
The secret ballot was largely boycotted by the workers. When the votes that were cast were counted they were 5000 to 7000 against acceptance of the award in New South Wales and Victoria.
Women's involvement in trade unions and their direct participation in industrial action has been the subject of growing interest for labour historians and industrial relations scholars. Some research has also concentrated on women's indirect participation to paid work. However just as this field of investigation has made inroads into the study of labour history, some have advised a return to ‘traditional’ concerns of institutional labour history. The following article takes up this debate through an investigation of the 1929 strike in the timber industry. It suggests that hitherto unexplored aspects of mobilisation may be more fully appreciated by analysing those closely associated with strikers and their unions. Specifically it emphasises the role of community and gender relations.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://wwwdocs.fce.unsw.edu.au/orgmanagement/WorkingPapers/WP104.pdf|title=The 1929 Timber Workers Strike: The Role of Community and Gender|format=PDF|date=|accessdate=2013-09-26}}</ref> Women played a particularly active role in the dispute holding weekly meetings, attending picket lines and collecting money.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwwdocs.fce.unsw.edu.au/orgmanagement/WorkingPapers/WP104.pdf |title=Anatomy of a Strike: Industrial and Community Responses to the 1929 Timber Workers Strike |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-07-03}}</ref> Several women were prosecuted and sent to gaol for collecting money for the strikers. There was considerable community and union support<ref>{{cite web|author=Issy Wyner |url=http://www.takver.com/history/myunion/myunion11.htm#1929 |title=Chapter 11: Strike! and the Ship Painters and Dockers Union |publisher=Takver.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-03}}</ref> mobilised for the strikers, which enabled them to survive on strike for so long.
After five months the strike came to an end on 24 June on the basis of a 48-hour week, but with an independent inquiry to be appointed into the financial condition of the industry. At the end of July seven union leaders, including [[Jock Garden]], the Secretary of the [[Labor Council of New South Wales|Trades and Labor Council]]; [[John Culbert (Australian politician)|John Culbert]], the Secretary of the Timber Workers Union; and the Chairman of the ACTU Disputes Committee were charged with "unlawful [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] by violence and threats of violence" to prevent timber workers from working. A jury subsequently acquitted all those charged.
==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://wwwdocs.fce.unsw.edu.au/orgmanagement/WorkingPapers/WP104.pdf The 1929 Timber Workers Strike: The Role of Community and Gender] (PDF) by Diane van den Broek, July 1995 * [http://www.takver.com/history/myunion/myunion11.htm#1929 Union support for the timber workers] – Ship Painters and Dockers Union * [http://www.reasoninrevolt.net.au/bib/PR0000174.htm Labour Day - Its significance and the life and times of E.J. Edward John Holloway] – speech by Bill Richardson 1971 *http://wwwdocs.fce.unsw.edu.au/orgmanagement/WorkingPapers/WP104.pdf {{Portal|Organized labour}}
{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1000118 |title=TIMBER WORKERS' STRIKE. |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=23 March 1929 |accessdate=26 September 2013 |page=1 |via=National Library of Australia}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1929 Timber Workers Strike}} [[Category:1929 labor disputes and strikes|Timber Workers Strike, 1929]] [[Category:Labour disputes in Australia]] [[Category:1929 in Australia|Timber Workers strike]] [[Category:Timber industry]]

revision.text:
[[File:Land surface temperature anomalies for June 17–24, 2012.jpg|thumb|Map of land surface temperature anomalies for June 17–24, 2012. The map depicts temperatures compared to the 2000–2011 average for the same eight-day period in June. (Land surface temperatures (LST) are distinct from the hot air temperatures that meteorological stations typically measure.)]] The '''Summer 2012 North American heat wave''' was one of the most severe [[heat waves]] in modern North American history. It resulted in more than 82 heat-related deaths across the [[United States]] and [[Canada]],<ref>{{cite web| author=[[Associated Press]] |url= http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/07/09/12642682-americans-get-relief-from-heat-but-severe-storms-loom?lite |title=Americans get relief from heat, but severe storms loom |publisher=msnbc.msn.com |date=2012-06-30 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Bruce Schreiner |author2=Roxana Hegeman |author3=Seth Borenstein |last-author-amp=yes |url=https://news.yahoo.com/nation-bakes-serious-heat-wave-hits-early-071629659.html;_ylt=A2KJjb3aIe9PhDEAUy7QtDMD |title=Nation bakes as serious heat wave hits early |publisher= [[Yahoo! News]] |date=2012-06-28 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> and an additional twenty-two lives were lost in the resultant [[June 2012 North American derecho]]. This long-lived, straight-line wind and its thunderstorms cut electrical power to 3.7 million customers.<ref name="reut630">{{cite news|agency=Reuters|author=Ian Simpson|date=2012-06-30|title=Storms leave 3.4 million without power in eastern U.S.|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=2012-06-30|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-usa-weather-stormbre85t02u-20120629,0,1801684.story}}</ref> Over 500,000 were still without power on July 6, as the heat wave continued.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news| url= http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/06/us/extreme-heat/index.html?hpt=us_c1 |title=Over 115 million bake in heat, with more scorching temps to come |publisher=CNN.com |date= July 7, 2012|accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> Temperatures generally decreased somewhat the week of July 9 in the east,<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/APb7cb808869a74c21960da4841c4fc520|title=US to get a reprieve from hot temperatures|date=9 July 2012|publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref> but the high pressure shifted to the west, causing the core of the hot weather to the build in the [[Mountain States]] and the southwest U.S. shifting eastwards again by mid-July. By early August, the core of the heat remained over the Southern Plains.<ref name="latimes.com">{{cite news|last=Nelson |first=Laura J. |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-heat-wave-relief-07072012,0,7425188.story |title=Heat relief is on way for East, Midwest, as high temps shift west |publisher=latimes.com |date=2012-07-07 |accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref><ref name="abcnews.go.com">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/nations-weather-16738371#.T_u9cfU1_Rg |title=U.S. News | National News - Latest Headlines, Videos, Photos - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=2006-05-04 |accessdate=2012-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712114947/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/nations-weather-16738371 |archivedate=July 12, 2012 }}</ref>
==Cause== [[File:Heat Wave.jpg|thumb|High pressure aloft traps heat near the ground, causing a heat wave]] The heat wave formed when high pressure aloft over the [[Baja California|Baja of Mexico]] strengthened and moved over the southern plains around June 20–23 and then spread east and northward, remaining fixed over the center of North America through July 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/news/story/2012-07-05/heat-wave-forecast/56048518/1 |title=Record-setting heat wave could break soon for millions â€ |publisher=Usatoday.com |date= July 5, 2012|accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Burt|first=Christopher|title=The Amazing June Heat Wave of 2012. Part 1: The West and Plains June 23-27|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/weatherhistorian/comment.html?entrynum=79|publisher=wunderground.com|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref>
The direct cause of the heat is that, under high pressure, the air subsides (sinks) toward the surface. This sinking air acts as a dome capping the atmosphere. This cap helps to trap heat instead of allowing it to lift. Without the lift there is little or no convection and therefore little or no convective clouds (cumulus clouds) with minimal chances for rain. The end result is a continual build-up of heat at the surface resulting in drought conditions over wide areas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Heat Index |publisher=US National Weather Service |url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/jetstream/global/hi.htm}}</ref>
This heat wave, like all extreme weather events, has its direct cause in a complex set of atmospheric conditions that produce short-term weather. However, weather occurs within the broader context of the climate, and many scientists agree that global warming has made it more likely that heat waves of this magnitude will occur.<ref name="autogenerated2"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Has global warming brought an early summer to the US? |publisher=''[[New Scientist]]''|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn21636-has-global-warming-brought-an-early-summer-to-the-us.html|date=28 March 2012|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref> A NASA-sponsored study<ref>Wang et al. (2015; JGR) DOI: 10.1002/2014JD023013 - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014JD023013/full</ref> indicates an increase in the drying tendency from spring to summer over the U.S. Central Plains, especially during the transition from June to July. The intensified deficit in precipitation is accompanied by increased downward shortwave radiation flux, tropospheric subsidence, enhanced evaporative fraction, and elevated planetary boundary layer height, all of which can lead to surface drying. These conditions are similar to those accompanying the 2012 drought<ref>"Could the 2012 drought in central U.S. have been anticipated? - A review of NASA working group research." http://cliserv.jql.usu.edu/paper/WG_2012Drought_paper.pdf</ref> and intense heat that occurred in mid-summer.
==Timeline of impacts==
===Beginning of heat wave=== The intense heat wave in the West was initiated around June 20–23 when the high pressure system centered over the Baja of California shifted upward into the plains<ref>{{cite web|title=AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION - 159 PM CDT WED JUN 20 2012|url=http://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/p.php?pid=201206201859-KBRO-FXUS64-AFDBRO|publisher=NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE BROWNSVILLE TX|accessdate=2012-08-24|date=June 20, 2012}}</ref> and caused temperatures to approach or even surpass 110 degrees for the next several days, breaking many records for the area.{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}}
The heat spread east from the [[Rocky Mountains]] and a massive [[high-pressure system]] over the Midwest caused extreme temperatures not seen on such a scale since the 1930s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Murphy |first=Kevin |url=https://news.yahoo.com/extreme-heat-spreads-across-u-breaks-records-230935013.html;_ylt=A2KJjb3pJO9PnH4AWarQtDMD |title=Extreme heat spreads across U.S., breaks records - Yahoo! News |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=2012-06-28 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> On June 25, 2012, [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]] tied its all-time high with a temperature of 105 °F (40.5 °C). On the same day a couple of 113 °F (45 °C) readings were recorded in [[Kansas]]. The heat was so strong that [[Alamosa, Colorado]] broke their daily records for six consecutive days. In [[Galveston, Texas]], the earliest 100 °F (38 °C) day ever was recorded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/alltime-record-highs-fall-in-p/67058 |title=All-Time Record Highs Fall in Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska |publisher=[[Accuweather]] |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> [[Hill City, Kansas]] was the warmest point in the [[United States]] on June 26, with the thermometer climbing to 115 °F (46.1 °C).<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2012/06/27/3679925/hill-city-high-temperature-hits.html |title=Hill City high temperature hits 115 again Wednesday |publisher=[[The Kansas City Star]] |date=2012-06-27|accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
Thousands of records were again broken on June 28. [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] tied its all-time record high with 106 °F (41.1 °C) while [[Indianapolis]] broke its monthly record at 104 °F (40 °C). More monthly records that day included [[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]] at 108 °F (42.2 °C) and [[Little Rock, Arkansas]] at 107 °F (41.7 °C).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.storm2k.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=112849&start=60 |title=STORM2K - RECORD HIGHS JUNE 2012 |publisher=Storm2k.org |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> The heat resulted in two boys from [[Bradley County, Tennessee|Bradley County]], [[Tennessee]] dying of [[hyperthermia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2012/7/6/229723/Heat-Caused-Death-Of-Two-Young-Boys.aspx |title=Heat Caused Death Of Two Young Boys In Bradley County - 07/06/2012 |publisher=Chattanoogan.com |date=2012-06-07 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
In the Mid South, from June 28 through June 30, many notable temperature extremes occurred. In [[Paducah, Kentucky]], June 29 witnessed an all time official record of {{convert| 108|F|C|1}}.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} In [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]], the same day witnessed {{convert| 109|F|C|1}}, one degree short of the state's all-time record for June. Perhaps more remarkable, [[Tennessee]] observed a handful of all-time record highs. [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] reached 109 °F (42.77 °C) on June 30, eleven degrees higher than the previous record. [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]] reached a high of {{convert| 105|F|C|1}}, while [[Chattanooga, Tennessee|Chattanooga]] reached {{convert| 107|F|C|1}}, an all-time high, on both June 30 and July 1. And, although not officially verified by the [[National Weather Service]] at this time, [[Smyrna, Tennessee]] recorded a reading of {{convert| 113|F|C|1}} on the 29th, which would in fact be the highest recorded temperature in the state.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burt |first=Christopher|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/weatherhistorian/comment.html?entrynum=80|title=The Amazing June Heat Wave of 2012 Part 2: The Midwest and Southeast June 28-30|date= 2012-07-01|publisher=wunderground.com|accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
In [[Fort Good Hope, Northwest Territories]], there was a streak of five consecutive days above 30 °C (86 °F) from June 21 to June 25 peaking at 35 °C (95 °F), quite possibly the longest heat wave in [[Canada]] at that time.<ref name=climate1>{{cite web |url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?StationID=27549&Month=6&Day=25&Year=2012&timeframe=2 |title=Daily Data | Canada's National Climate Archive |publisher=Climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=7 July 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121216030313/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?StationID=27549&Month=6&Day=25&Year=2012&timeframe=2 |archive-date=2012-12-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Further south, on June 19, 20 and 21, [[Toronto]] experienced its first official early season heat wave (In Canada, a heat wave is defined as three or more consecutive days with temperatures at or above 90 °F (32 °C)), with temperatures ranging between 92.1 °F (33.4 °C) and 94.1 °F (34.5 °C) and the minimum temperature on June 20 not dropping below 75.9 °F (24.4 °C).<ref name=climate1/> On both July 4 and July 6, Toronto reached 36.3 °C (97.3 °F)<ref name=climate1/> and on July 17, the city hit 36.8 °C (98.3 °F),<ref name=climate1/> making this the hottest day of the year in the city and the 5th record daily high of the summer.
===Spread to Southeastern U.S.=== The high pressure ridge continued to slide eastward and centered itself over [[Tennessee]], causing hundreds of records to be matched or surpassed for multiple states, including [[Illinois]], [[Indiana]], [[Kentucky]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[North Carolina]], and [[Washington D.C.]], among others.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
The scorching heat continued on June 29 when [[Athens, Georgia]] and [[Columbia, South Carolina]] set new all-time record high temperatures of 109 °F. [[Washington, D.C.]] recorded its highest June temperature ever at 104 °F (40 °C), and [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] and [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] were warm enough to tie their all-time record highs at 104 °F (40 °C) and 105 °F (40.6 °C) respectively.<ref>{{cite news|last=Samenow |first=Jason |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capital-weather-gang/post/washington-dc-ties-record-high-of-101/2012/06/29/gJQAiiRmBW_blog.html |title=Washington, D.C. shatters all-time June record high, sizzles to 104 - Capital Weather Gang |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2012-06-29 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> On June 30, [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] set a new all-time record high temperature of 106 °F.
The [[Mid-Atlantic States]] did not escape the heat. On June 29, [[Salisbury, Maryland]] recorded a monthly record high of {{convert|101|F|0}},<ref name= NCDC >{{cite web | url = http://www.nws.noaa.gov/climate/xmacis.php?wfo=akq | title = NOWData - NOAA Online Weather Data | accessdate = 2014-06-02 | publisher = [[National Weather Service]] Wakefield, VA }}</ref> while [[Baltimore]] ([[Maryland Science Center|DMH]]) reached {{convert|106|F|0}} on June 29,<ref>[http://weather-warehouse.com/WeatherHistory/PastWeatherData_BaltimoreDowntown_Baltimore_MD_July.html]</ref> setting a similar month of June record.
===Northeast and Midwest=== While still affecting the Southeastern and Great Plains regions of the U.S., the heat wave continued to spread northward into the New England area around July 7 and 8, leading to temperatures surpassing 90 °F.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
Chicago's [[O'Hare International Airport]] tied its all-time [[4th of July]] record of 102 °F (38.9 °C) which was set back in 1912. Not far from O'Hare, the official measuring station for the city of Chicago, the [[village]]s of [[Park Ridge, Illinois|Park Ridge]], [[Niles, Illinois|Niles]], [[Norridge]] as well as much of the Chicago metropolitan area recorded a temperature of 104 °F (40 °C). Some places north of Chicago got even hotter. [[Caledonia, Wisconsin]], just south of [[Milwaukee]] reached 107 °F. Actual air temperatures were close to 110 °F in and around the city of [[Allegan, Michigan]]. St. Louis endured a string of ten straight days with temperatures above 100 °F, ending on July 7.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/streak-of--degree-weather-in-st-louis-area-hits/article_69ca6f80-b235-5bfd-9985-9fcc82eb498e.html |title=Streak of 100-degree weather in St. Louis area hits five days |publisher=StLToday.com |date=2012-07-03 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> As of July 7, three deaths in St. Louis were attributed to the heat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/news/heat-wave-20120706 |title=Midwest Can't Get Any Relief from Oppressive Heat |publisher=weather.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
As of July 6, Chicago has had four official {{convert|100|F|C}} or higher temperature readings, one on June 28, along with three in July, culminating with an official near-record shattering high of {{convert|103|F|C}} at O'Hare on both July 5 and 6, reaching {{convert|106|F|C|1}} near [[Chicago]], the following day reaching 98 °F shortly before 11 AM at O'Hare International Airport, but much of the Chicago metro area west and south of the airport reached or exceeded 100 degrees, marking the fourth consecutive day of 100-degree heat across the Chicago area. The city proper tied the old record of three consecutive 100-degree days which was set back in August 1947. Normally, the highest temperature recorded in a typical Chicago summer is around {{convert|95|F|C}}, a streak of 3 days above {{convert|90|F|C}} constitutes a "heat wave", and the thermometer reaches or surpasses {{convert|100|F|C}} only once every five to ten years. The Chicago temperatures exceeded the [[1995 Chicago heat wave]], which claimed over 750 lives, although humidity and registered dew points were higher during that heat wave.<ref>{{cite web| date= July 6, 2012 |url=http://blog.chicagoweathercenter.com/2012/07/tims-weather-world-is-this-heat-wave-chicagos-worse-ever.html |title=Tim's Weather World: Is this heat wave Chicago's worst - Chicago Weather Center |publisher=Blog.chicagoweathercenter.com |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> Through the first five days of July, the mean temperature in Chicago averaged {{convert|86.4|F|C}}, {{convert|13.2|F-change|0}} above normal, the hottest since 1911.<ref>{{cite web|date =July 6, 2012 |url=http://blog.chicagoweathercenter.com/2012/07/oppressive-heat-spills-into-friday-with-the-hottest-temps-since-chicagos-deadly-july-12-16-1995-heat.html |title=Oppressive heat spills into Friday with the hottest temps since Chicago's deadly July 12-16, 1995 heat wave 17 years ago - Chicago Weather Center |publisher=Blog.chicagoweathercenter.com |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> Two deaths are confirmed so far from the heat in [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]], and two other lives were lost in a [[train derailment]] blamed on the heat.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-07-06/news/ct-met-chicago-heat-0706-20120706_1_heat-wave-chicago-braces-scorching-heat |title=Intense heat in Chicago a factor in two deaths, many disruptions |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date= July 6, 2012|accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> An additional death in [[Rock County, Wisconsin|Rock County]], [[Wisconsin]] has been noted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beloitdailynews.com/heat-related-death-noted-in-rock-county/article_c4d49bd2-c789-11e1-9aea-001a4bcf887a.html |title=Heat related death noted in Rock County |publisher=[[Beloit Daily News]] |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
The heat caused highways to buckle in [[Illinois]], [[North Carolina]] and Wisconsin.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/AP9f9eca44bfeb44d18d50fc862387b805 Temperatures across US cool slightly but still hot] July 8, 2012</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kesling |first=Ben |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303962304577510900094398194 |title=Unwavering Heat Wave Grips U.S. - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2012-07-09 |accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref>
After a brief respite from the extreme heat, the [[Mid-Atlantic States]] resumed observation of record highs by the end of the first week of July. Maryland has been particularly hard-hit, with eight deaths so far, including four on July 5.<ref>{{cite web |title=Update: Heat-Related Deaths Rise To 9 In Md. |url=http://wusa9.com/news/article/211834/373/Heat-Related-Deaths-Rise-To-8-In-Md- |publisher=[[WUSA (TV)]] |date=6 July 2012 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> [[Cumberland, Maryland]] recorded a monthly record of {{convert|104|F|C|1}} on July 8. [[Bremo Bluff, Virginia]] recorded an astounding {{convert|109|F|C}}, which is an all-time-record high on July 8.<ref name="wunderground1">{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/climate/extremes.asp|title=NCDC Record Extremes|accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
The [[Northeastern United States]] suffered the worst of the [[heat wave]] on July 7–8. Even normally cool plateau regions experienced highs over 90 °F. [[Laurel Mountain, Pennsylvania]], near [[Johnstown, Pennsylvania|Johnstown]], reached {{convert|95|F|C|1}} on July 8, beating the previous all-time-record high by 2 °F (1 °C). Similarly, on July 7, daily record highs were broken in several cities in eastern Pennsylvania, including [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]], [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania|Lancaster]], and [[Chambersburg, Pennsylvania|Chambersburg]], which each reached {{convert|101|F|C|1}}.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wunderground U.S. Records |url=http://www.wunderground.com/climate/extremes.asp|accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref> [[Pittsburgh]] reached 98° on July 7, which, while not a daily record (101° in 1988), was the hottest temperature recorded there since it reached 100° on July 15, 1995. Cleveland, Ohio reached 101 °F on July 21. Akron-Canton airport said that it was its warmest year on record with an all time July record of 101 °F on July 7th.<ref name="wunderground2">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.gov/cle/2012NotableEvents|title=NCDC Record Extremes in Northeast Ohio}}</ref> On July 8, the heat eased across the east as the high pressure center shifted west, causing hot weather once again build in the mountain states and the southwest U. S.<ref name="latimes.com"/><ref name="abcnews.go.com"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Heat's impact hits roads, thermostats |url=http://www.wral.com/weather/story/11266073/ |publisher=WRAL.com |date=2012-06-29 |accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref>
===Heat continues in Great Plains, spreads into New England=== After some modification in the heat during the past week over the midwest and northeast, the jet once again moved further north into Canada allowing intense heat to build across eastern North America. On July 15, Temperatures reached {{convert|109|F|C|1}} in [[Pierre, South Dakota]].
On July 17, the temperature at [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] Metro Airport climbed to {{convert|102|F|C|1}}, the third plus 100 degree day thus far in July. The average July maximum temperature is {{convert|83|F|C|1}}.
The Northeastern states also experienced a second round of heat, with temps again returning to the 90's. [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]] reached {{convert|101|F|C|1}} on July 18, a daily record high. The same day, [[Newark, New Jersey]] reached {{convert|104|F|C|1}}, a daily record.<ref name="wunderground1"/> [[Teterboro Airport]], [[New Jersey|NJ]] recorded a monthly record high of {{convert|103|F|C|1}}. [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania|PA]] hit a temperature of {{convert|108|F|C|1}}. Triple-digit temperatures even reached [[Hartford, Connecticut]], where, on July 18, the city reached {{convert|100|F|C|1}}, which was a monthly record high.<ref name="wunderground1"/>
As of July 25, St. Louis, Missouri endured its 16th straight day of plus {{convert|100|F|C|1}} heat with 27 of the past 28 days exceeding this temperature, with high 90s forecast over the next few days. 24 deaths have been attributed to the heat in St. Louis metro area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/cooler-weather-could-bring-relief-to-consumers-hit-hard-by/article_5ad605a4-e111-53d4-8a2b-d92edc71079d.html |title=Cooler weather could bring relief to St. Louis-area consumers hit hard by utility bills |publisher=Stltoday |date=2012-07-26 |accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref>
===Heat wave continues in the Southwest=== As of August 13, 90 to 100-degree plus heat was still occurring in the desert Southwest and in many western states, associated with the same upper-level ridge of high pressure. The heat wave continued at one location or another within the [[Contiguous US]] for over two months' worth of consecutive days. A major [[jet stream]] dip and associated upper-level [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] of low pressure brought rain, storms, and cooler weather to parts of the eastern and central US, slightly lessening [[2012 North American drought|drought impacts]] in some areas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Western states bake under extended heat wave|url=http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/western-states-bake-under-extended-heat-wave/article_5ac089d8-1485-58a7-bc24-3061c587d06f.html|accessdate=14 August 2012|newspaper=Rapid City Journal|date=13 August 2012}}</ref>
===Other impacts=== Wildfires raged across the western United States during the time of the heat wave,<ref>{{cite news|title=Wildfires rage amid heat wave in western United States|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/08/world/americas/08iht-heat.5.6554976.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2012-08-24|date=July 8, 2007}}</ref> in part attributable to the dry conditions caused by the heat. The [[Waldo Canyon fire]] in Colorado attracted the most attention after spreading into Colorado Springs and charring hundreds of homes (investigators determined it to be human caused, rather than from "the heat"), but large wildfires also burned throughout Utah, Wyoming, Montana, New Mexico, Arizona and Idaho.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/fires/main/usa/20120629-westernUS.html |title= NASA Maps Heat Wave Fueling Wildfires in the Rockies |publisher=NASA |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
The heat wave also contributed to the record-shattering [[2012 North American drought]], which caused massive crop failures throughout the Midwest. The drought affected 80% of the contiguous US as of July 24, and was considered the worst drought since the 1950s but not yet on the scale of devastation endured during the [[dust bowl]] of the 1930s.<ref>{{cite news|last=Suhr|first=Jim|title=U.S. drought worst since mid-'50s|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2018706003_drought17.html|accessdate=26 July 2012|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=17 July 2012}}</ref>
===Severe storms=== {{main|Summer heat wave of 2012 derecho series}} [[File:6-29-2012 Derecho.jpg|thumb|Composite radar image as the [[June 2012 North American derecho]] moved from Indiana to Virginia.]] On July 26, 2012, the heat wave contributed to the formation of a multi-bow [[Late July 2012 North American derecho|serial derecho]] in the Midwest and Northeast.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
On June 29–30, 2012, the heat and humidity from the heat wave caused a small thunderstorm in Iowa to develop into a violent and unprecedented [[June 2012 North American derecho|derecho]], which tracked across the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic regions of the United States while causing 80 MPH or higher winds, doing hundreds of millions of dollars in damage, and downing trees and power lines, leaving four million people in the eastern U. S. without power.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/nation/east-coast-storms-kill-13-cause-wide-power-outages-1.3815085 |title=East Coast storms kill 13, cause wide power outages |publisher=[[Newsday.com]] |date=30 June 2012 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
==See also== *[[2012 North American drought]] *[[June 2012 North American derecho]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=scorching-heat-roasts-eastern-unite Scorching Heat Roasts Eastern U.S.] July 3, 2012 [[Scientific American]] *[http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/19/for-the-sweltering-little-relief-in-sight/ For the Sweltering, Little Relief in Sight] July 19, 2012 *[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/26/us/rise-in-weather-extremes-threatens-infrastructure.html ''Weather Extremes Leave Parts of U.S. Grid Buckling''] July 25, 2012 [[NYT]] *[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-07-26/the-age-of-scarcity ''The Age of Scarcity''] July 26, 2012 [[BusinessWeek]] {{Heat wave|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:2012 heat waves]] [[Category:Heat waves in the United States|2012 06]] [[Category:Heat waves in Canada|2012 06]] [[Category:2012 natural disasters in the United States]] [[Category:Summer weather events]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox President |image = Ali Asghar Soltanieh.jpg |imagesize = | honorific-prefix = | name = {{lang|fa|علی اصغر سلطانیه}}
Ali Asghar Soltanieh | honorific-suffix = | order = | office = Representative of Iran to the [[IAEA]] | term_start = 1 September 2006 | term_end = 1 September 2013 | president = [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] | predecessor = [[Mohammad Mehdi Akhondzadeh]] | successor = [[Reza Najafi]] | term_start1 = 1 September 1982 | term_end1 = 1 September 1987 | president1 = [[Ali Khamenei]] | predecessor1 = ''Inaugural holder'' | successor1 = Khalil Mousavi | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|10|1|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] | alma_mater = [[Utah State University]] | residence = | religion = [[Shi'a Islam]] }} '''Ali Asghar Soltanieh''' {{Audio-IPA|Ali Asghar Soltanieh from Iran pronunciation.ogg|pronunciation}} ({{lang-fa|علی‌اصغر سلطانیه}}, born 1 October 1950) was Iran's ambassador to the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] in [[Vienna]]. He served the position from 1982 to 1987 and for a second term in 2006 until 2013. ==Early life and education== Soltanieh was born in Tehran on 1 October 1950.[http://www.g77.org/vienna/CV%20Ambassador%20Soltanieh.pdf CV of Soltanieh] G77 He studied at [[Utah State University]] in the [[United States]].[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2008/12/iran-nuclear-co.html Nuclear secrets or nuclear pride?] ''Los Angeles Times'' 13 December 2008 ==Career== Soltanieh is a nuclear physicist by training and worked as associate professor at faculties of science and international relations in various universities between 1988 and 1997. He taught courses in [[nuclear physics]]. In the 1990s he was involved, as a nuclear physicist and senior diplomat, in the capacity of special envoy, delegate, chief negotiator, and invited speaker in numerous international events on disarmament and international security, such as NPT, CWC, BWC, CTBT, CCW, and has worked closely with the relevant international scientific and technical organizations such as [[UN]], [[IAEA]], [[OPCW]], and other specialized international organizations such as [[WHO]], [[ILO]], [[Inter-Parliamentary Union]] (IPU), [[Queensland Investment Corporation|QIC]], [[WMO]], [[TWAS]] and [[ICDO]]. He has published several papers in aforementioned areas. For the three years immediately prior to taking up his position as the Iran's envoy to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, Soltanieh was the head of Iran's National Escort Team for IAEA Inspections; a member of delegation to the IAEA board of governors and general conference; and a member of the negotiating team, Iran-EU3/EU negotiation on nuclear energy. On 27 August 2013, it was reported that Reza Najafi replaced Soltanieh as the Iran's ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.{{cite news|title=Iran names new envoy to IAEA, extending makeover of nuclear team|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/27/us-iran-nuclear-idUSBRE97Q0OD20130827|accessdate=27 August 2013|work=Reuters|date=27 August 2013|author=Yeganeh Torbati|location=Dubai}} ==Personal life== Soltanieh is married and has three children. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-dip}} {{succession box | before=[[Mohammad Mehdi Akhondzadeh Basti]] | title=Ambassador of [[Iran]] to [[IAEA]] | years=2006–2013 | after=[[Reza Najafi]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soltanieh, Ali Asghar}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Utah State University alumni]] [[Category:Iranian academics]] [[Category:International Atomic Energy Agency officials]] [[Category:Iranian diplomats]] [[Category:Iranian Shia Muslims]]

{{chembox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 419771945 | ImageFile1 = | ImageSize1 = | ImageName1 = | Name = Ammonium uranyl carbonate | IUPACName = uranium(VI)dioxide tetra-ammonium tricarbonate | OtherNames = uranyl ammonium carbonate
AUC | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers }} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = UO2CO3·2(NH4)2CO3 | MolarMass = 522.199 g/mol | Density = 2.72 | Solubility = Insoluble | MeltingPt = Decomposes between 165 °C and 185 °C | Appearance = lemon-yellow crystalline }} | Section3 = {{Chembox Structure | Structure_ref ={{cite journal|last1=Graziani|first1=R.|last2=Bombieri|first2=G.|last3=Forsellini|first3=E.|title=Crystal structure of tetra-ammonium uranyl tricarbonate|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions|date=1972|issue=19|pages=2059|doi=10.1039/DT9720002059}} | CrystalStruct = monoclinic | SpaceGroup = ''C''2/''c'' | PointGroup = | LattConst_a = 10·68 | LattConst_b = 9·38 | LattConst_c = 12·85 | LattConst_alpha = | LattConst_beta = 96.45° | LattConst_gamma = | LattConst_ref = | LattConst_Comment = | UnitCellVolume = 1279 | UnitCellFormulas = 4 }} }} '''Ammonium uranyl carbonate''' (UO2CO3·2(NH4)2CO3) is known in the [[uranium]] processing industry as '''AUC'''{{Cite journal|date=2007-03-01|title=The precipitation of ammonium uranyl carbonate (AUC): Thermodynamic and kinetic investigations|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0304386X06002313|journal=Hydrometallurgy|language=en|volume=85|issue=2–4|pages=163–171|doi=10.1016/j.hydromet.2006.08.011|issn=0304-386X|last1=Mellah|first1=A.|last2=Chegrouche|first2=S.|last3=Barkat|first3=M.}} and is also called '''uranyl ammonium carbonate'''. This compound is important as a component in the conversion process of [[uranium hexafluoride]] (UF6) to [[uranium dioxide]] (UO2).{{Cite journal|last=Krishnan|first=V. N.|last2=Visweswaraih|first2=M. S.|last3=Shringarpure|first3=P. D.|last4=Koppiker|first4=K. S.|last5=Date|first5=V. G.|title=Studies on the preparation and characterisation of ammonium uranyl carbonate (AUC)|url=http://inis.iaea.org/Search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:24000267|language=English}} The ammonium uranyl carbonate is combined with [[steam]] and [[hydrogen]] at 500–600 °C to yield UO2. In another process aqueous [[uranyl nitrate]], known as uranyl nitrate liquor (UNL) is treated with [[ammonium bicarbonate]] to form ammonium uranyl carbonate as a solid precipitate.{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Timothy J.|last2=Sweet|first2=Lucas E.|last3=Meier|first3=David E.|last4=Mausolf|first4=Edward J.|last5=Kim|first5=Eunja|last6=Weck|first6=Philippe F.|last7=Buck|first7=Edgar C.|last8=McNamara|first8=Bruce K.|date=2015-05-22|title=Dehydration of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate to uranyl nitrate trihydrate under ambient conditions as observed via dynamic infrared reflectance spectroscopy|journal=Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, and Explosives (CBRNE) Sensing XVI|volume=9455|pages=945504|doi=10.1117/12.2179704}} This is separated from the solution, dried with [[methanol]] and then calcinated with hydrogen directly to UO2 to obtain a sinterable grade powder. The ex-AUC uranium dioxide powder is free-flowing, relatively coarse (10 µ) and porous with specific surface area in the range of 5 m2/g and suitable for direct pelletisation, avoiding the granulation step. Conversion to UO2 is often performed as the first stage of [[nuclear fuel]] fabrication.{{Cite book|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/305398098|title=Comparison of Nuclear Fuels for TREAT: UO2 vs. U3O8|last=Glazoff|first=Michael|last2=J. van Rooen|first2=Isabella|last3=D. Coryell|first3=Benjamin|last4=J. Parga|first4=Clemente|date=2016-05-05}} The AUC process is followed in South Korea{{Cite journal|date=1994-05-01|title=Crystallization characteristics of ammonium uranyl carbonate (AUC) in ammonium carbonate solutions|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0022311594902682|journal=Journal of Nuclear Materials|language=en|volume=209|issue=3|pages=306–314|doi=10.1016/0022-3115(94)90268-2|issn=0022-3115|last1=Tae-Joon|first1=Kim|last2=Kyung-Chai|first2=Jeong|last3=Jin-Ho|first3=Park|last4=In-Soon|first4=Chang|last5=Cheong-Song|first5=Choi}} and Argentina.{{Cite journal|last=Dominguez|first=C. A.|last2=Leyva|first2=A. G.|last3=Marajofsky|first3=A.|title=Conditions study of ammonium uranyl tricarbonate precipitation through ammonium carbonate|url=http://inis.iaea.org/Search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:24046621|language=Spanish}} In the AUC route, calcination, reduction and stabilization are simultaneously carried out in a vertical fluidized bed reactor. In most countries, sinterable grade UO2 powder for nuclear fuel is obtained by the [[ammonium diuranate]] (ADU) process, which requires several more steps. Ammonium uranyl carbonate is also one of the many forms called [[yellowcake]]; in this case it is the product obtained by the heap leach process. ==References== ==Extra reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Yi-Ming|first1=Pan|last2=Che-Bao|first2=Ma|last3=Nien-Nan|first3=Hsu|title=The conversion of UO2 via ammonium uranyl carbonate: Study of precipitation, chemical variation and powder properties|journal=Journal of Nuclear Materials|date=September 1981|volume=99|issue=2–3|pages=135–147|doi=10.1016/0022-3115(81)90182-3|bibcode=1981JNuM...99..135Y}} *{{cite journal|last1=Kan-Sen|first1=Chou|last2=Ding-Yi|first2=Lin|last3=Mu-Chang|first3=Shieh|title=Precipitation studies of ammonium uranyl carbonate from UO2F2 solutions|journal=Journal of Nuclear Materials|date=May 1989|volume=165|issue=2|pages=171–178|doi=10.1016/0022-3115(89)90246-8|bibcode=1989JNuM..165..171K}} *{{cite journal|last1=Mellah|first1=A.|last2=Chegrouche|first2=S.|last3=Barkat|first3=M.|title=The precipitation of ammonium uranyl carbonate (AUC): Thermodynamic and kinetic investigations|journal=Hydrometallurgy|date=March 2007|volume=85|issue=2–4|pages=163–171|doi=10.1016/j.hydromet.2006.08.011}} {{Uranium compounds}} [[Category:Ammonium compounds]] [[Category:Uranyl compounds]] [[Category:Carbonates]] [[Category:Nuclear materials]]

revision.text:
A '''back-to-back''' connection is the direct [[electrical connection|connection]] of the output of one device to the input of a similar or related device.
==Telecommunications== In [[telecommunication]]s, a back-to-back connection can be formed by connecting a [[transmitter]] directly to a receiver without a [[transmission line]] in between.<ref>[[Federal Standard 1037C]] and from [[MIL-STD-188]]</ref> This is used for equipment measurements and testing purposes. The back-to-back connection eliminates the effects of the [[transmission medium]].
In some cases, the output of a receiving device is instead connected to the input of a transmitting device.
== Power transmission == A back-to-back connection for [[electric power transmission]] is a [[High-voltage direct current|high-voltage direct-current]] (HVDC) system with both ends in the same [[Electrical substation|switchyard]]. This is used to couple asynchronously operated [[power grid]]s or for connecting power grids of different [[frequency|frequencies]] where no DC transmission line is necessary.
== Electronics == In [[electronics]], a back-to-back connection is the connection of two identical or similar components in [[Series circuit|series]] with the opposite polarity. This is used to convert polarised components to non-polar use. Common examples include: * [[electrolytic capacitor]]s * [[zener diode]]s
== Notes == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Telecommunications techniques]] [[Category:High-voltage direct current]] [[Category:Capacitors]] [[Category:Diodes]]
{{telecomm-stub}}
